feed.title: Comments on AngularJS vs Knockout – SPA Routing/History (8 of 9)
feed.subtitle: A Technical Community for IT Professionals

entry.title: By: Cheng Fan
entry.content:
Nice article! It’s good to see how Angular does the routing in code for someone never used it.
I just open-sourced a mini SPA framework that I put together with Knockout being the core component:

knockout-spa
https://github.com/onlyurei/knockout-spa
A mini (but full-fledged) SPA framework built on top of Knockout, Require, Director, jQuery, Sugar that powers RentEver.com

entry.title: By: Chuck
entry.content: Major problem with Angular/Javascript routing is did not work on IE (All version)

entry.title: By: Eli Weinstock-Herman (tarwn)
entry.content:
kpolo: I admit I’m not crazy about it either, but I got used to the syntax as I went. I felt the same way about RequireJS when I started looking at it, and that at least has them as separate arguments in the define/require calls. I’m sure they spent some time thinking abut this before they went down that path, so it will be interesting if they (AngularJS contributors) find a new direction as the project contiues to grow or if this remains the method going forward.

pagerjs user: I took a look at pagerjs, it’s different from the libraries I looked at in that it is basically doing what I did with the dynamic templates, but using id’s to define the routes. I haven’t used it, but I feel like trying to build something large and manage a lot of routes with this model would be a bit ungainly.

entry.title: By: pagerjs user
entry.content:
What about http://pagerjs.com/ ?

I have started looking into it for knockout routing.

What is your impressions?

entry.title: By: kpolo
entry.content:
This is the kind of stuff in Angular/Javascript that is nuts:

sampleApp.config([‘$routeProvider’, function (routeProvider) {
…
);
}]);

So the config method takes in an array of strings and functions? This is a cognitive debt for the developer. There is nothing intuitive about it. There is a difference between a framework that works for you (e.g. Spring) and a framework that you work for (Angular!).

As Angular matures, in a few years, you will look at this code and be dumbfounded.
